Topics include limited fluctuation credibility theory, greatest accuracy credibility theory, credibility premium, Buhlmann models, Buhlmann-Straub models, empirical Bayesian methods in nonparametric and semiparametric cases, and the insurance problem. This course, combined with MATH 4427, prepares students to take the Exam C (Construction and Evaluation of Actuarial Models) of the Society of Actuaries.

MATH4432.NAME: Statistical Machine Learning
MATH4432.DESCRIPTION: This course provides students with an extensive exposure to the elements of statistical machine learning in supervised and unsupervised learning with real world datasets. Topics include regression, classification, resampling methods, model assessment, model selection, regularization, nonparametric models, boosting, ensemble methods, random forests, kernel methods, support vector machines, neural networks, and some standard techniques in unsupervised learning such as clustering and dimensionally reduction. Lab sessions on using R or Python in data analysis with machine learning methods will be conducted in class. Scientific reports and/or poster presentations are required for project evaluations.

MATH5312.COURSEID: MATH 5312 - Advanced Numerical Methods II (3 units)
MATH5312.NAME: Advanced Numerical Methods II
MATH5312.DESCRIPTION: Direct and iterative methods. Programming techniques and softwares libraries. Sparse solvers, Fast algorithms, multi-grid and domain decomposition techniques.
MATH5312.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Understand direct and iterative algorithms for solving linear systems, and their convergence theory.
2.Identify suitable algorithms to solve linear equations arising from practical science and engineering problems, and implement them on a computing platform.
3.Understand algorithms and theories of other numerical linear algebra problems including the least squares problem and the eigenvalue problem.

MATH5353.COURSEID: MATH 5353 - Multiscale Modeling and Computation for Non-equilibrium Flows (3 units)
MATH5353.NAME: Multiscale Modeling and Computation for Non-equilibrium Flows
MATH5353.DESCRIPTION: Introduction of the Navier-Strokes equations and the flow modeling in the hydrodynamic scale. The derivation of the Boltzmann equation in the kinetic scale. The basic mathematical analysis of the Chapman-Enskog expansion and the numerical methods for the Boltzmann equation. The multiscale modeling from the kinetic to the hydrodynamic scales and the discretized governing equations. The study of non-equilibrium transport phenomena in gas dynamics, radiative and heat transfer, and plasma physics.
MATH5353.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Derive the Navier-Stokes equations in the hydrodynamic scale.
2.Model the particle transport and collision and derive the Boltzmann equation in kinetic scale.
3.Extend the kinetic scale modelling to other scales and construct the corresponding governing equations.
4.Develop numerical scheme for multiscale transport equations.
5.Use multiscale method to study transport problems in rarefied gas dynamics, radiative and heat transfer, and plasma simulation.

MATH5470.NAME: Statistical Machine Learning
MATH5470.DESCRIPTION: This course covers methodology, major software tools and applications in statistical learning. By introducing principal ideas in statistical learning, the course will help students understand conceptual underpinnings of methods in data mining. The topics include regression, logistic regression, feature selection, model selection, basis expansions and regularization, model assessment and selection; additive models; graphical models, decision trees, boosting; support vector machines; clustering.
MATH5470.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Describe the basic procedures in data analysis.
2.Explain the principles behind statistical learning tools.
3.Analyze data with real data.
4.Draw meaningful implications in decision making.
5.Write a good project report and help decision making in practice.

MATH6380O.COURSEID: MATH 6380O - Deep Learning: Toward Deeper Understanding (3 units)
MATH6380O.NAME: Deep Learning: Toward Deeper Understanding
MATH6380O.DESCRIPTION: This course is inspired by Stanford Stats 385, Theories of Deep Learning, taught by Prof. Dave Donoho, Dr. Hatef Monajemi and Mr. Vardan Papyan. The aim of this course is to be provide graduate students who are interested in deep learning a variety of mathematical and theoretical understanding of neural networks which are currently available in research, in addition to some preliminary tutorials. Students with mathematical maturity on approximation theory, optimization, and statistics will be helpful.

MATH6771.COURSEID: MATH 6771 - Professional Development Training in Mathematics (1 unit)
MATH6771.NAME: Professional Development Training in Mathematics
MATH6771.DESCRIPTION: This one-credit course aims at providing research postgraduate students basic training in teaching skills, research management, career development in and outside academia, and related professional skills in Mathematics. This course lasts for one semester, and is composed of a number of mini-workshops or tasks. Graded PP, P or F.
MATH6771.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Exhibit effective skills in the teaching of Mathematics.
2.Apply essential communication skills for classroom teaching.
3.Recognize the features of the departmental online teaching system.
4.Prepare mathematics research papers, teaching notes and presentation slides using software (Tex).
5.Develop basic understandings of data science and reserch data management.
6.Demonstrate an understanding of the applications of knowledge and abilities of mathematics in industry.

MATH4981D.COURSEID: MATH 4981D - Independent Study: Stochastic Processes (3 units)
MATH4981D.NAME: Independent Study: Stochastic Processes
MATH4981D.DESCRIPTION: This is an independent study course which studies continuous time Markov chains in detail.  Applications to queueing theory will also be discussed. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH6912I.COURSEID: MATH 6912I - Reading Course: Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning (1 unit)
MATH6912I.NAME: Reading Course: Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning
MATH6912I.DESCRIPTION: Graphical Model. EM algorithm, Approximate Inference with applications. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6912J.COURSEID: MATH 6912J - Reading Course: Numerical Methods for Fluid-solid Heat Transfer Problems (1 unit)
MATH6912J.NAME: Reading Course: Numerical Methods for Fluid-solid Heat Transfer Problems
MATH6912J.DESCRIPTION: The student will read a few articles on heat transfer in fluid-solid coupled systems and the numerical methods for such problems. He will then report to the class. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6912K.COURSEID: MATH 6912K - Reading Course: Iterative Regularization and Variational Inference (1 unit)
MATH6912K.NAME: Reading Course: Iterative Regularization and Variational Inference
MATH6912K.DESCRIPTION: Explicit and inexplicit regularization in statistical learning, Reproducible Kernel Hilbert Space, Stein Variational Gradient Inference. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH3332.NAME: Data Analytic Tools
MATH3332.DESCRIPTION: This course will introduce to the students some mathematical analysis tools that are useful for data analysis. The topics include Fourier analysis, wavelet analysis, function expansions, and basic functional analysis (Banach space, Hilbert spaces, linear operators, contract mapping, etc), and basic convex analysis (subgradient, convex conjugate).

MATH4824B.COURSEID: MATH 4824B - Machine Learning for Natural Language Processing (3 units)
MATH4824B.NAME: Machine Learning for Natural Language Processing
MATH4824B.DESCRIPTION: This course provides an introduction to statistical machine learning algorithms for natural language processing and using programming tools such as Python (including packages such as NLTK and Tensorflow) to implement them for real problems. It will use some of the following practical problems such as text classification, information extraction, sequence modeling, text inference, QA system, etc. as illustrations to demonstrate the power of the statistical learning algorithms.

MATH4981E.COURSEID: MATH 4981E - Independent Study: Further Topics in Financial Economics (3 units)
MATH4981E.NAME: Independent Study: Further Topics in Financial Economics
MATH4981E.DESCRIPTION: In this course, we shall explore various topics related to financial economics. Topics included: Utility theory and its application in portfolio management and decision making, further topics in derivative pricing etc.. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4981F.COURSEID: MATH 4981F - Independent Study: Algebraic Number Theory (1 unit)
MATH4981F.NAME: Independent Study: Algebraic Number Theory
MATH4981F.DESCRIPTION: In this course the student will lead independent study on the Class Field theory, which characterizes abelian extensions of number fields. This is the first advanced topic beyond algebraic number theory. Background of algebraic number theory is preferred. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983A.COURSEID: MATH 4983A - Independent Study: Introduction to Logic and Set Theory (3 units)
MATH4983A.NAME: Independent Study: Introduction to Logic and Set Theory
MATH4983A.DESCRIPTION: This is a reading course which focus on the fundamental philosophy of mathematics. We begin with the basic propositional calculus and proofs. Then the Zermelo-Fraekel axioms of set theory is studied in detail. Finally the axiom of choice and its equivalences are introduced together with their roles in undergraduate mathematics. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH5285.NAME: Applied Analysis
MATH5285.DESCRIPTION: Contraction mapping theorem, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, Basics of Hilbert Space theory, Operator theory in Hilbert Spaces, Basics of Banach space theory, Convex analysis.
MATH5285.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Explain the key ideas and concepts behind various analytical techniques.
2.Identify situations where analytical techniques are applicable.
3.Recognize limitations of the analytical techniques.
4.Develop extension of generalization for the techniques.
5.Implement the techniques to problems in various situations.

MATH5450.NAME: Stochastic Processes
MATH5450.DESCRIPTION: Theory of Markov processes, second order stationary theory, Poisson and point processes, Brownian motion, Martingales and queueing theory.
MATH5450.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Introduce the general concept of stochastic process and Markov chain.
2.Study the properties of Markov chain and its limiting distributions.
3.Study the periodic Markov chain and its properties.
4.Study martingale convergence theory and option sampling theory.
5. Study Brownian motion and its properties.

MATH6150G.COURSEID: MATH 6150G - Representation Theory and Number Theory (3 units)
MATH6150G.NAME: Representation Theory and Number Theory
MATH6150G.DESCRIPTION: This main focus of this course is the theory of automorphic forms. Automorphic forms are a generalization of the idea of periodic functions in Euclidean space to general reductive Lie groups. The study of such functions is an important branch in representation theory and has applications in number theory. This course will start from a review of some basic topics includes Galois groups of number fields, decomposition subgroups, Dedekind zeta functions, Artin zeta functions, modular forms and Hecke algebras. We will then discuss Tate thesis, automorphic forms on classical groups and Langlands conjectures. Some knowledge about Lie theory such as Lie groups and Lie algebras is helpful to understand the course.

MATH6250I.NAME: Riemannian Geometry
MATH6250I.DESCRIPTION: This is an introductory course on Riemannian Geometry for graduate students in pure/applied mathematics or physics, and advanced undergraduate students who are strongly interested in geometry and topology. The goal of the course is to equip students with essential knowledge on Riemannian Geometry for research or further studies in related fields such as Geometric Analysis, General Relativity, etc. Topics will include Gauss's Theorema Egregium, Riemannian manifolds, parallel transport and holonomy, geodesics, curvature tensors, Jacobi fields, etc. If time permits, contemporary topics such as geometric flows will be covered at the end of the course.

MATH6380P.COURSEID: MATH 6380P - Advanced Topics on Deep Learning (3 units)
MATH6380P.NAME: Advanced Topics on Deep Learning
MATH6380P.DESCRIPTION: This course is an extension of Stanford Stats 385, Theories of Deep Learning, taught by Prof. Dave Donoho, Dr. Hatef Monajemi and Mr. Vardan Papyan. The aim of this course is to provide graduate students who are interested in deep learning some state-of-the-art mathematical and theoretical understanding of neural networks, in addition to some preliminary tutorials. It includes, but is not limited to, harmonic analysis perspectives on convolutional networks, statistical learning theory on generalization ability, and non-convex  optimization methods. Familiarity on python programming with modern neural networks and mathematical maturity on approximation theory, optimization, and statistics will be helpful.

MATH6912L.COURSEID: MATH 6912L - Reading Course: Mathematical Problems of Solid Mechanics (3 units)
MATH6912L.NAME: Reading Course: Mathematical Problems of Solid Mechanics
MATH6912L.DESCRIPTION: This reading course will give introduction to elasticity theory and will discuss the recent advances in mathematical models of defects in solids. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912M.COURSEID: MATH 6912M - Reading Course: An Introduction to Plasma and Its Simulation (3 units)
MATH6912M.NAME: Reading Course: An Introduction to Plasma and Its Simulation
MATH6912M.DESCRIPTION: This course introduces fundamental concept in plasma physics and magnetohydrodynamics (MHD). The topics include kinetic theory, the Vlasov equation, and the relation between kinetic and fluid models. The Unified Gas Kinetic Scheme (UGKS) will be introduced, which simulates plasma from the Vlasov equation in the kinetic scale to all kinds of MHD equations in the hydrodynamic scale. Multiple numerical test cases will be used to validate Plasma-UGKS. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912N.COURSEID: MATH 6912N - Reading Course: Polyhedral and Semi-algebra Geometry (4 units)
MATH6912N.NAME: Reading Course: Polyhedral and Semi-algebra Geometry
MATH6912N.DESCRIPTION: This course is to study spaces constructed from polytopes, convex sets, and some semi-algebraic sets. The purpose is to obtain knowledge for students to further study the geometric measures of such spaces by extending Minkowski product of convex bodies to semi-algebraic sets. The subjects include the following five aspects: 1. Polytopes, polyhedral, and polyhedral spaces 2. Combinatorial curvatures of graphs, polytopal cell complexes 3.Topological classification of polygonal surfaces with nonnegative curvature 4. Minkowski algebra of polyconvex sets 5. Semi-algebraic sets: (i) Triangulation of semi-algebraic sets, (ii) triviality of semi-algebraic maps, (iii) Euler numbers of semi-algebraic sets, (iv) Minkowski product of semi-algebraic sets, (v) Elementary mixed volumes of polyconvex semi-algebraic sets. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912O.COURSEID: MATH 6912O - Reading Course: Modeling Materials Defects and Randomness (3 units)
MATH6912O.NAME: Reading Course: Modeling Materials Defects and Randomness
MATH6912O.DESCRIPTION: This reading course will give introduction to defects in solids and stochastic processes, and will discuss the recent advances in modeling approaches. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912P.COURSEID: MATH 6912P - Reading Course: Non-equilibrium Flow (1 unit)
MATH6912P.NAME: Reading Course: Non-equilibrium Flow
MATH6912P.DESCRIPTION: This reading course will give introduction to gas-kinetic theory, statistical mechanics and non-equilibrium kinetic theory. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6915.NAME: Scientific Computation Seminar
MATH6915.DESCRIPTION: This course will expose PG students to the current research and new development in scientific computation and provide them with opportunities to make social contacts with the speakers from both the local and international academic communities. Graded P or F.
MATH6915.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Attend 6 seminars related to the scientific computation from the home or other departments in the whole semester.

MATH4983B.COURSEID: MATH 4983B - Independent Study: Basic Number Theory (3 units)
MATH4983B.NAME: Independent Study: Basic Number Theory
MATH4983B.DESCRIPTION: Divisibility of integers, prime numbers, unique factorisation of prime numbers, congruences, Chinese remainder theorem, prime power moduli, prime modulus, primitive roots and power residues, quadratic residues, quadratic reciprocity, arithmetic functions, the Mobius inversion formula, Diophantine equations. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983D.NAME: Independent Study
MATH4983D.DESCRIPTION: Advanced undergraduate topics independently studied under the supervision of a faculty member. May be repeated for credit if different topics are studied. May be graded P/F or letter grade.

MATH6912S.COURSEID: MATH 6912S - Reading Course: Introduction to Data Analysis (1 unit)
MATH6912S.NAME: Reading Course: Introduction to Data Analysis
MATH6912S.DESCRIPTION: This reading course will cover: Part one - Introduction to Machine Learning Methods, and Part two - Application of Machine Learning Methods to Real Data Projects. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH4822F.COURSEID: MATH 4822F - Symmetry and Representation Theory (3 units)
MATH4822F.NAME: Symmetry and Representation Theory
MATH4822F.DESCRIPTION: The course is an introduction to representation theory from historical perspective, in particular the development of mathematics in Fourier analysis, the Erlangen program and the Langlands program. We focus on examples of solving problems in analysis, geometry and number theory by representing elements of abstract algebraic structures as linear transformations of vector spaces.

MATH4983C.COURSEID: MATH 4983C - Independent Study: Commutative Algebra (3 units)
MATH4983C.NAME: Independent Study: Commutative Algebra
MATH4983C.DESCRIPTION: Noetherian rings, localisation of modules, Dedekind domain, completion, dimension theory. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983E.COURSEID: MATH 4983E - Independent Study: Model Theory (3 units)
MATH4983E.NAME: Independent Study: Model Theory
MATH4983E.DESCRIPTION: Model theory is the core part of mathematical logic. The objective of this reading course is to introduce the basic setup of the subject which finally leads to the Gödel completeness theorem. Applications include the inprovablility of the negation of the axiom of choice from the standard axioms of set theory. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983F.COURSEID: MATH 4983F - Independent Study: Introduction to Mathematics of Face Classification (3 units)
MATH4983F.NAME: Independent Study: Introduction to Mathematics of Face Classification
MATH4983F.DESCRIPTION: The course introduces clustering technique to divide a set of face images into different groups or clusters so that each resulting cluster contains faces with similar characteristics. Students will learn and compare the performance of different clustering techniques by applying these methods on different datasets and evaluating their performances. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983G.COURSEID: MATH 4983G - Independent Study: Statistical Techniques of Wind Speed Forecast (3 units)
MATH4983G.NAME: Independent Study: Statistical Techniques of Wind Speed Forecast
MATH4983G.DESCRIPTION: In this research project, the ensemble model post-processing techniques of wind speed forecast at selected weather stations in Hong Kong will be investigated. To improve the short-term trend in the probability forecasts of the wind speed, a Bayesian calibration algorithm called the Sequential Importance Resampling (SIR) will be developed for location-specific nowcast or very-short-range forecast of wind speed. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983H.COURSEID: MATH 4983H - Independent Study: Numerical Methods for Hamilton-Jacobi Equations (3 units)
MATH4983H.NAME: Independent Study: Numerical Methods for Hamilton-Jacobi Equations
MATH4983H.DESCRIPTION: The course introduces finite difference methods to solve Hamilton-Jacobi equations. Students will learn the mathematics fundamentals of the nonlinear first order partial differential equations and will implement some of the numerical schemes. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983I.COURSEID: MATH 4983I - Independent Study: Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (3 units)
MATH4983I.NAME: Independent Study: Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks
MATH4983I.DESCRIPTION: The student will be trained to use conditional generative adversarial networks for applications of image synthesis. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983J.COURSEID: MATH 4983J - Independent Study: Topological and Geometric Data Reduction and Visualization (3 units)
MATH4983J.NAME: Independent Study: Topological and Geometric Data Reduction and Visualization
MATH4983J.DESCRIPTION: This course is open to graduates and senior undergraduates in applied mathematics, statistics, and engineering, who are interested in learning from data. Students with other backgrounds such as life sciences are also welcome, provided you have certain maturity of mathematics. It will cover wide topics in geometric (principal component analysis and manifold learning, etc.) and topological data reduction (clustering and computational homology group, etc.). Students with background of linear and abstract algebra, basic probability and multivariate statistics, basic stochastic process (Markov chains), convex optimization; familiarity with Matlab, R, and/or Python, etc. preferred.  Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH4983K.COURSEID: MATH 4983K - Independent Study: Face Detection and Image Recognition in Deep Learning (2 units)
MATH4983K.NAME: Independent Study: Face Detection and Image Recognition in Deep Learning
MATH4983K.DESCRIPTION: Deep learning has been widely used in visual recognition systems nowadays. In this course, the student will be trained to use deep learning methods and image processing knowledge for applications of face detection and image recognition. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH5281.NAME: Partial Differential Equations
MATH5281.DESCRIPTION: This is an introductory postgraduate course on Partial Differential Equations (PDEs). We will start with the classical prototype linear PDEs, and introduce a variety of tools and methods. Then we will extend our beginning theories to general situation using the notion of Sobolev spaces, Holder space and weak solutions. We will prove the existence, uniqueness, regularity and other properties of weak solutions.
MATH5281.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Recognize the types of second-order PDEs as typified by classical equations of mathematical physics, such as the wave equation, heat equation and Laplace equation.
2.Identify and describe the major theories of general PDEs.
3.Apply the tools of calculus, linear algebra and real analysis in a coherent way to PDE problems.
4.Apply the knowledge of PDEs to physical sciences and engineering, and physically interpret the solutions.
5.Use different methods, such as Fourier transform, separation variables, characteristics, similarity, power series to solve PDEs.

MATH6380I.COURSEID: MATH 6380I - Introduction to Molecular Modeling (3 units)
MATH6380I.NAME: Introduction to Molecular Modeling
MATH6380I.DESCRIPTION: This course will introduce fundamental principles of statistical physics and computer simulation methods at the molecular scale, including Monte Carlo methods and molecular dynamics.

MATH6380Q.COURSEID: MATH 6380Q - Topological and Geometric Data Reduction and Visualization (3 units)
MATH6380Q.NAME: Topological and Geometric Data Reduction and Visualization
MATH6380Q.DESCRIPTION: This course is a mathematical introduction to data analysis and visualization with a perspective of topology and geometry. Topics covered include: classical linear dimensionality reduction, the principal component analysis (PCA) and its dual multidimensional scaling (MDS). Extensive application examples in biology, finance, and information technology are presented along with course projects.

MATH6450E.COURSEID: MATH 6450E - Computer Age Statistical Inference (3 units)
MATH6450E.NAME: Computer Age Statistical Inference
MATH6450E.DESCRIPTION: This course is open to post graduates in applied mathematics, statistics, and engineering who are interested in learning from data. It covers advanced topics in statistical learning and inference, featured with various applications in computer vision, human genetics, and text mining. It emphasizes the integration of statistical modeling and algorithm design for statistical inference. Examples includes variational inference with its applications in deep learning. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH6912Q.COURSEID: MATH 6912Q - Reading Course: Introduction to Computational Acoustics (3 units)
MATH6912Q.NAME: Reading Course: Introduction to Computational Acoustics
MATH6912Q.DESCRIPTION: This reading course will introduce the challenges in computational aeroacoustics and give an overview of the methods, analysis and new ideas proposed to solve those problems. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912R.COURSEID: MATH 6912R - Reading Course: Random Matrix and Random Network (3 units)
MATH6912R.NAME: Reading Course: Random Matrix and Random Network
MATH6912R.DESCRIPTION:
This reading course will cover: i) spectrum of adjacency matrix of undirected random
network; ii) spectrum of directed random regular graph; iii) smallest singular value of non-Hermitian random matrix. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912T.COURSEID: MATH 6912T - Reading Course: Kac-Moody Groups and Applications (3 units)
MATH6912T.NAME: Reading Course: Kac-Moody Groups and Applications
MATH6912T.DESCRIPTION: Kac-Moody groups is an important class of infinite dimensional groups. This course will help the students to go through several important literatures including papers by Tits, Braverman-Kazhdan-Patnack and Garland. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912U.COURSEID: MATH 6912U - Reading Course: Introduction to Modular Forms (2 units)
MATH6912U.NAME: Reading Course: Introduction to Modular Forms
MATH6912U.DESCRIPTION: We will read the book "A First Course in Modular Forms" by Fred Diamond, Jerry Shurman. This course discusses modular forms, elliptic courves and modularity conjecture. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6915A.NAME: Scientific Computation Seminar
MATH6915A.DESCRIPTION: This course will expose PG students to the current research and new development in scientific computation and provide them with opportunities to make social contacts with the speakers from both the local and international academic communities. Graded P or F.

MATH4983L.COURSEID: MATH 4983L - Independent Study: Quantum Groups (1 unit)
MATH4983L.NAME: Independent Study: Quantum Groups
MATH4983L.DESCRIPTION: This is a guided study of the representation theory of quantum groups. We will study the basic structure of Hopf algebra, its finite dimensional representations, the construction of universal R matrix, and survey its applications in quantum geometry and physics. Familiarity with Lie algebra is preferred. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983M.COURSEID: MATH 4983M - Independent Study: Complex Analysis (3 units)
MATH4983M.NAME: Independent Study: Complex Analysis
MATH4983M.DESCRIPTION: This complex analysis course mainly focuses on the application of residue calculus. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983N.COURSEID: MATH 4983N - Independent Study: Ordinary Differential Equations (3 units)
MATH4983N.NAME: Independent Study: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH4983N.DESCRIPTION: This is a standard course in ordinary differential equations, which includes first order and second order differential equations and their initial value problems. The method of Laplace transform is discussed also, and finally systems of first order differential equations are studied by methods of matrix algebra. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983O.COURSEID: MATH 4983O - Independent Study: Conformal Mapping (3 units)
MATH4983O.NAME: Independent Study: Conformal Mapping
MATH4983O.DESCRIPTION: This is a reading course on conformal mappings. The first issue is the proof of the Riemann mapping theorem. Then the subject of univalent functions is introduced and we prove the initial case of the Bieberbach conjecture as well as the Koebe distortion theorem. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983P.COURSEID: MATH 4983P - Independent Study: Mathematical Finance (3 units)
MATH4983P.NAME: Independent Study: Mathematical Finance
MATH4983P.DESCRIPTION: This course is directed to those students who would like to acquire an introduction to the fundamental principles of financial mathematics. Topics include bond portfolio management and immunization, horizon rate of return, mean-variance mathematics, Markowitz portfolio theory, capital asset pricing models, investment performance analysis, utility optimization in investment decisions. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6912V.COURSEID: MATH 6912V - Reading Course: Spectral Compressed Sensing (1 unit)
MATH6912V.NAME: Reading Course: Spectral Compressed Sensing
MATH6912V.DESCRIPTION: This course provides an introduction to spectral compressed sensing and their applications. Both convex and non-convex methods will be included, and we will focus on the theoretical analysis with optimal sampling and computation complexity. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH4983Q.COURSEID: MATH 4983Q - Independent Study: Advanced Topics in Loss Models and Financial Mathematics (3 units)
MATH4983Q.NAME: Independent Study: Advanced Topics in Loss Models and Financial Mathematics
MATH4983Q.DESCRIPTION: In this course, the students are required to work on a specified topic related to financial mathematics. Project topic can be chosen from one of the following areas: (1) Numerical method in derivative pricing, (2) Advanced optimal portfolio selection theory, and (3) Loss model and its application in risk management. If time permitted, the students will also explore some statistical methods for model calibration. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983R.COURSEID: MATH 4983R - Independent Study: Mathematical Models in Economics: Voting and Matching (3 units)
MATH4983R.NAME: Independent Study: Mathematical Models in Economics: Voting and Matching
MATH4983R.DESCRIPTION: This topic course provides student an opportunity to integrate and apply mathematical tools to analyze problems in economics and social science. The topics include (i) fair allocations, (ii) matching schemes, (iii) voting methods and social choice theory, (iv) proportional representation and apportionment schemes. The student is required to do oral presentation of selected technical papers on these topics and work on some homework problems. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983S.COURSEID: MATH 4983S - Independent Study: Ordinary Differential Equations (3 units)
MATH4983S.NAME: Independent Study: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH4983S.DESCRIPTION: This independent study course is an introduction of the theory of ordinary differential equations in the complex domain. We focus on the local behaviour of the solutions of Fuchsian equations as well as the global behaviour by means of the monodromy representations. Finally we will describe special solutions via monodromies as an application. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983T.COURSEID: MATH 4983T - Independent Study: Multivariate Analysis (3 units)
MATH4983T.NAME: Independent Study: Multivariate Analysis
MATH4983T.DESCRIPTION: Multivariate analysis is based on the statistical principle of multivariate statistics, which involves observation and analysis of more than one statistical outcome variable at a time. The classical topics of multivariate analysis are covered in this course, including inferences of means and covariance matrices, canonical correlation, discriminant analysis, multivariate ANOVA, principal components analysis, and factor analysis. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983U.COURSEID: MATH 4983U - Independent Study: Algebraic Curves (3 units)
MATH4983U.NAME: Independent Study: Algebraic Curves
MATH4983U.DESCRIPTION: This course is about the basics of algebraic curves. The content is in Griffith's book "Introduction to Algebraic Curves". Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983V.COURSEID: MATH 4983V - Independent Study: Use Machine Learning Technique to Control Air Quality (3 units)
MATH4983V.NAME: Independent Study: Use Machine Learning Technique to Control Air Quality
MATH4983V.DESCRIPTION: As an emerging technique, machine learning algorithms can capture the complex nonlinear relationships with interactions. Compared to the traditional statistical method, machine learning is more reliable for the air pollution analysis. PM2.5 and O3 are the two secondary ambient pollutants. In this study, we plan to combine machine learning techniques, ground observation, satellite data to generate high resolution PM2.5 products. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983W.COURSEID: MATH 4983W - Independent Study: Arithmetic of Elliptic Curves (3 units)
MATH4983W.NAME: Independent Study: Arithmetic of Elliptic Curves
MATH4983W.DESCRIPTION: This is an independent study on arithmetic of elliptic curves. Students will read a book on the subject and meet regularly with the instructor. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983X.COURSEID: MATH 4983X - Independent Study: Using CFD Software to Simulate the Dispersion of Pollutants (2 units)
MATH4983X.NAME: Independent Study: Using CFD Software to Simulate the Dispersion of Pollutants
MATH4983X.DESCRIPTION: This study involves engaging the ANSYS CFD software to simulate the transport and fate of PM2.5 and bioaerosols in a clinic setting. Field measurements will be performed on site to validate the model. Necessary corrections will be made in the model to achieve an accurate simulation of the dispersion behavior of PM2.5 and microorganisms in the subject setting. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983Y.COURSEID: MATH 4983Y - Independent Study: Numerical Methods for Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponent (3 units)
MATH4983Y.NAME: Independent Study: Numerical Methods for Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponent
MATH4983Y.DESCRIPTION: The course introduces mathematical foundations and numerical methods for computing the finite-time Lyapunov exponent (FTLE) for visualizing and extracting important coherent structures in dynamical systems. Students will pick up various theoretical tools including theories of ordinary differential equations (ODE's) and numerical methods for ODE's and hyperbolic partial differential equations (PDE's). Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH5471.COURSEID: MATH 5471 - Statistical Learning Models for Text and Graph Data (3 units)
MATH5471.NAME: Statistical Learning Models for Text and Graph Data
MATH5471.DESCRIPTION: This course will introduce a number of important statistical methods and modeling principles for analyzing large-scale data sets, with a focus on complex data structures such as text and graph data. Topics covered include sequential models, structure prediction models, deep learning attention models, reinforcement learning models, etc., as well as open research problems in this area.
MATH5471.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Demonstrate machine learning algorithm design skills for data analytics tasks.
2.Analyze the quality of results to domain problems.
3.Develop a program that can handle existing real problems.

MATH5520.NAME: Interest Rate Models
MATH5520.DESCRIPTION: Theory of interest rates, yield curves, short rates, forward rates.  Short rate models: Vasicek model and Cox-Ingersoll-Ross models.  Term structure models: Hull-White fitting procedure.  Heath-Jarrow-Morton pricing framework.  LIBOR and swap market models, Brace-Gatarek-Musiela approach.  Affine models.
MATH5520.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Explain fixed-income markets and the roles of the fixed-income derivatives.
2.Apply advanced mathematical tools for fixed-income modeling.
3.Identify risk factors of fixed-income derivatives and formulate major classes of fixed-income models accordingly.
4.Evaluate the effectiveness of various models for different sectors of fixed-income derivatives.
5.Analyze exotic derivatives, identify proper pricing models and strategies for hedging.

MATH6150H.COURSEID: MATH 6150H - Introduction to Cluster Algebra (3 units)
MATH6150H.NAME: Introduction to Cluster Algebra
MATH6150H.DESCRIPTION: "How do you describe a matrix where the determinant of every submatrix is positive?" The answer to this simple question has a rich algebraic structure. The theory of Cluster Algebra was introduced in 2000 to study the above problem of "total positivity". This new theory quickly becomes one of the most important research areas in mathematics, which finds applications in representation theory, combinatorics, hyperbolic geometry, algebraic geometry, dynamical systems, quantum theory and mathematical physics. This is an introductory course for graduate and advanced undergraduate students. After treating carefully the basics, we will survey some of the research topics in cluster algebra, covering the required backgrounds, if necessary. Students should seek approval from the course instructor to take the course.

MATH6250J.COURSEID: MATH 6250J - Introduction to Enumerative Geometry (3 units)
MATH6250J.NAME: Introduction to Enumerative Geometry
MATH6250J.DESCRIPTION: This is an introduction to enumerative geometry, mirror symmetry, and topics beyond. Gromov Witten theory (GW) enumerates the number of Riemann surfaces in Calabi Yau (CY) manifolds. It originated from IIA string theory and became celebrated in enumerative algebraic geometry. Physics predicted GW theory is equivalent to type IIB string theory on another CY manifolds called Mirror. Such prediction generates a lot of research directions. We shall introduce both the GW theory and mirror symmetry conjecture. In the end of the course we shall include subjects such as bosonic strings or Chern Simons theories, with an eye to peek into the non-enumerative realm. To take this course, one is required to know basic concepts in Undergraduate mathematics such as the definitions of Riemann surfaces, sheaf cohomology and Chern classes. The language of schemes will be used throughout the course. Backgrounds in path integrals or QFT will be helpful.

MATH6380R.NAME: Theoretical Neuroscience
MATH6380R.DESCRIPTION: Theoretical neuroscience aims to understand the principle mechanisms of brain function using mathematical models. It develops concepts and insights that has been crucial for experimental design and data interpretation. The technical challenges it faces, such as analyzing nonlinear systems with broadly interacted units, are also relatable to other application scenarios of mathematical modeling. We will introduce classic models and results on the main topics of the field, including neural coding of sensory information, dynamics of neural circuits, decision making, memory, and learning. As a rapidly developing field with many open questions, we will also discuss the latest research in these topics. Experience in programming using python, Matlab, etc. is required. No prior knowledge of neurobiology is formally required but is encouraged, and we will introduce the necessary background in the course. Students without prerequisites should seek approval from the instructor to take the course.

MATH6380S.COURSEID: MATH 6380S - Fundamentals in Integrated Engineering (4 units)
MATH6380S.NAME: Fundamentals in Integrated Engineering
MATH6380S.DESCRIPTION: The students will be introduced to various approaches to perform quantitative analysis through real-world examples. Within the context of an engineering challenge, the students will learn how to select different tools, how to use different approaches, and how to acquire necessary knowledge and skills. Students should seek approval from the instructor to take this course.

MATH6450F.COURSEID: MATH 6450F - Advanced Algorithms and Theory of Machine Learning (3 units)
MATH6450F.NAME: Advanced Algorithms and Theory of Machine Learning
MATH6450F.DESCRIPTION: This is an advanced graduate course for students who are already familiar with machine learning. The goal is to explore some of the current active research topics in machine learning, through lectures, paper readings and discussions. The topics covered in the course include modern deep learning models and algorithms, representation learning, small sample learning, generative models, and the mathematical theory of deep learning. Students without prerequisites should seek approval from the instructor to take the course.

MATH6912W.COURSEID: MATH 6912W - Reading Course: Topics in Geometric PDEs: The Yamabe Problem (3 units)
MATH6912W.NAME: Reading Course: Topics in Geometric PDEs: The Yamabe Problem
MATH6912W.DESCRIPTION: This introductory course will show that how to use PDE techniques to solve geometric problems. We will introduce techniques including concentration compactness and blow up analysis. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH6912X.COURSEID: MATH 6912X - Reading Course: Research Writing in Machine Learning (3 units)
MATH6912X.NAME: Reading Course: Research Writing in Machine Learning
MATH6912X.DESCRIPTION: The course provides a training on scientific writing of research papers in machine learning. It is tailored to participants' interests with selected topics from deep learning, differential privacy, robust learning, false-discovery-rate control, etc. Students should seek instructor's approval to register for this course.

MATH4900.COURSEID: MATH 4900 - Academic and Professional Development (1 unit)
MATH4900.NAME: Academic and Professional Development
MATH4900.DESCRIPTION: This course is for academic and professional development of students. The course arranges seminars and small group activities to expose students to mathematics in real life, explore their possible career choice, and enhance the interactions between students and faculties. Activities may include seminars, workshops, advising and sharing sessions, interaction with faculty and teaching staff, and discussion with student peers or alumni. Graded P or F. For MATH students only.

MATH4984B.COURSEID: MATH 4984B - Independent Study: Hilbert Schemes of Points on Surfaces (3 units)
MATH4984B.NAME: Independent Study: Hilbert Schemes of Points on Surfaces
MATH4984B.DESCRIPTION:
This course is on the study of the Hilbert schemes of points on surfaces. It uses the
book by Zhenbo Qin. We will study the basic knowledge of Hilbert schemes, Nakajima's work on Hilbert schemes. If time permits, we will also study the cohomology ring structure of Hilbert schemes. The student will meet the instructor at least once a week to present the materials and discuss with the instructor on the materials. The student should seek the instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984C.COURSEID: MATH 4984C - Independent Study: Advanced Technologies for Fine Grained Entity Typing (3 units)
MATH4984C.NAME: Independent Study: Advanced Technologies for Fine Grained Entity Typing
MATH4984C.DESCRIPTION: This course will study the fine grained entity typing. Student will use programming tools and machine learning models to conduct the research. The student is expected to learn the knowledge in NLP and gain research experience. The student will meet the instructor at least once a week to present the materials and discuss with the instructor on the materials. The student should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984D.COURSEID: MATH 4984D - Independent Study: Predict Air Quality by Using Machine Learning Technique (3 units)
MATH4984D.NAME: Independent Study: Predict Air Quality by Using Machine Learning Technique
MATH4984D.DESCRIPTION: As the two most notorious ambient pollutants, O3 and PM2.5, exert adverse health impacts on human beings. It is still unclear how these two pollutants change under the climate change scenario. In this study, the student needs first to apply the KZ filter to de-trend the air quality time series. The purpose of processing this step is to remove the noise from the time series. The second step is to build up the relationship between the air quality time series and the meteorological time series. We expect to quantify the climate impacts on the air quality via this project. The student should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984E.COURSEID: MATH 4984E - Independent Study: Numerical Study of Partial Differential Equations (3 units)
MATH4984E.NAME: Independent Study: Numerical Study of Partial Differential Equations
MATH4984E.DESCRIPTION: The course covers topics that will allow students to get familiar with finite difference, finite volume for the solution of elliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic partial differential equations; related numerical analysis and iterative methods. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH5472.COURSEID: MATH 5472 - Computer Age Statistical Inference with Applications (3 units)
MATH5472.NAME: Computer Age Statistical Inference with Applications
MATH5472.DESCRIPTION: This course is designed for RPg students in applied mathematics, statistics, and engineering who are interested in learning from data. It covers advanced topics in statistical learning and inference, with emphasis on the integration of statistical models and algorithms for statistical inference. This course aims to first make connections among classical topics, and then move forward to modern topics, including statistical view of deep learning. Various applications will be discussed, such as computer vision, human genetics, and text mining.
MATH5472.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Describe the basic procedures in data analysis.
2.Explain the principles behind statistical inference.
3.Analyze real data.
4.Draw meaningful implications in decision making.
5.Write a good report.
6.Implement algorithms for statistical inference.

MATH6150I.COURSEID: MATH 6150I - Combinatorics of Crystal Bases (3 units)
MATH6150I.NAME: Combinatorics of Crystal Bases
MATH6150I.DESCRIPTION:
Crystal bases are discrete objects that encode useful structure in representations of 
Lie algebras. This topics course will develop the theory of crystal bases in a self-contained way from a combinatorial point of view.  Our ultimate goal is to see how crystals arise in the representation theory of quantum groups. As we investigate the theory, we will survey several important classical topics in algebraic combinatorics, such as Young tableaux, insertion algorithms, the Littlewood-Richardson rule, and Stanley symmetric functions. The course will be accessible for first year graduate students with some exposure to abstract algebra that are interested in algebraic combinatorics or representation theory. Students without course prerequisite should seek approval from the course instructor to take the course.

MATH6170C.COURSEID: MATH 6170C - Introduction to Elliptic Curves and Modular Forms (3 units)
MATH6170C.NAME: Introduction to Elliptic Curves and Modular Forms
MATH6170C.DESCRIPTION: The course covers the general cubic equation, the Weierstrass model and reduction mod p. Mordell's Theorem on finite generation of rational points of elliptic curves and its proof: Heights and descent.  Lattices and Weierstrass parametrization. Endomorphism structure and Complex multiplication. Constructing L-functions for elliptic curves. The construction of modular functions and forms. The j-function and singular moduli. Special values of L-functions. Some knowledge about algebraic geometry and complex analysis will be helpful. Students without course prerequisite should seek approval from the course instructor to take the course.

MATH6913A.COURSEID: MATH 6913A - Reading Course: Introduction to Turbulent Flows (3 units)
MATH6913A.NAME: Reading Course: Introduction to Turbulent Flows
MATH6913A.DESCRIPTION: The course will cover statistical description of turbulent flows; the scales of turbulent motion; direct numerical simulation; turbulent viscosity models. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913B.COURSEID: MATH 6913B - Reading Course: Wavelet and Nonlinear Approximation (3 units)
MATH6913B.NAME: Reading Course: Wavelet and Nonlinear Approximation
MATH6913B.DESCRIPTION: The course covers Fourier transform, time-frequency Analysis, multi-resolution analysis, orthogonal wavelet, nonlinear approximation of piecewise smooth functions, curvelet. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913C.COURSEID: MATH 6913C - Reading Course: Continuum Models of Linear and Nonlinear Elasticity (3 units)
MATH6913C.NAME: Reading Course: Continuum Models of Linear and Nonlinear Elasticity
MATH6913C.DESCRIPTION: The reading course will give introduction to elasticity theory and recent advances in nonlinear elasticity theories. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4983Z.COURSEID: MATH 4983Z - Independent Study: High Dimensional Probability in Data Science (3 units)
MATH4983Z.NAME: Independent Study: High Dimensional Probability in Data Science
MATH4983Z.DESCRIPTION: This is an independent course on the application of high dimensional probability in data science. The main focus will be various concentration inequalities and their applications. The course will cover the first 4 chapters of the book "High Dimensional Probability" by Roman Vershynin. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984F.COURSEID: MATH 4984F - Independent Study: Educational Data Analysis (1 unit)
MATH4984F.NAME: Independent Study: Educational Data Analysis
MATH4984F.DESCRIPTION:
This is an independent course on analyzing real data in education. Students will read
some materials on the subject and meet regularly with the instructor in Zoom or on
campus. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984G.COURSEID: MATH 4984G - Independent Study: AI-based Forecasting Model for Air Quality (3 units)
MATH4984G.NAME: Independent Study: AI-based Forecasting Model for Air Quality
MATH4984G.DESCRIPTION: The statistical regression and specific computational intelligence-based models will be studied in this course for the forecasting of hourly NO2 concentrations. Further, a novel approach, based on regression models, principal component analysis (PCA) will be used to analyze the correlations of different predictor variables between meteorology and air pollutants. This course will show how to quantify the wind and temperature impact on air quality. The student should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984H.NAME: Independent Study: Optimization
MATH4984H.DESCRIPTION: This course gives a brief introduction on mathematical optimization with a focus on convex Optimization. Topics include: Convex sets and convex functions, Convex optimization Problems, Duality, and Applications. The student should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984I.COURSEID: MATH 4984I - Independent Study: Theoretical and Numerical Computation of Shallow Water Equations (3 units)
MATH4984I.NAME: Independent Study: Theoretical and Numerical Computation of Shallow Water Equations
MATH4984I.DESCRIPTION: The course will focus on the study of shallow water equations theoretically and numerically. Firstly, based on mass and momentum conservation, the shallow water equations will be constructed and the mathematical properties will be analyzed. Secondly, based on the finite volume formulation, the corresponding numerical schemes will be constructed in one and two dimensional space. Thirdly, the numerical scheme will be applied to the shallow water flow and the dam breaking problem. The students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984J.COURSEID: MATH 4984J - Independent Study: Statistical Learning for Ranking (3 units)
MATH4984J.NAME: Independent Study: Statistical Learning for Ranking
MATH4984J.DESCRIPTION: Ranking occurs in diverse areas. Examples include QS ranking of universities, competitive sports such as horse racing. There are various statistical approaches to handle this type of problems. In this course, we will introduce methods for solving ranking problems and apply them to some real data. The student should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984K.COURSEID: MATH 4984K - Independent Study: Advanced Topics in Financial Economics (3 units)
MATH4984K.NAME: Independent Study: Advanced Topics in Financial Economics
MATH4984K.DESCRIPTION: This is an independent study course. Students will be asked to work on a project on some topics in financial/actuarial mathematics. Topics includes (1) the application of statistics in portfolio management/risk management or (2) numerical algorithm for pricing complex financial derivatives. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984L.COURSEID: MATH 4984L - Independent Study: Machine Learning Technique (3 units)
MATH4984L.NAME: Independent Study: Machine Learning Technique
MATH4984L.DESCRIPTION: A novel ensemble back-propagation neural network approach will be developed and implemented to estimate the spatial concentration of NO2 over East Asia. The long-term trend, as well as the high concentration hotspots of NO2, will be analyzed carefully based on the generated spatial map of NO2. We expect to quantify the emission control impacts over different countries on the NO2 ambient concentration from the long-term perspective. The student should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984M.COURSEID: MATH 4984M - Independent Study: Algebraic Number Theory and Lattice-based Cryptography (1 unit)
MATH4984M.NAME: Independent Study: Algebraic Number Theory and Lattice-based Cryptography
MATH4984M.DESCRIPTION: This course is divided into two parts. The first part is an introduction to algebraic number theory, focusing on the first 5 chapters of Marcus book “Number fields”. The second part is to read some recent papers on modular-lattice cryptosystem, a new lattice-based cryptography which utilizes algebraic number theory. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4995.COURSEID: MATH 4995 - Capstone Project for Data Science (3 units)
MATH4995.NAME: Capstone Project for Data Science
MATH4995.DESCRIPTION: This is a project-based course that trains students on applying computational and analytical tools (matrix computation, Fourier and wavelet transform, convex optimization, etc.) to real-world data analysis problems (recommendation system, signal processing, computer vision, etc.). Familiarity with a programming language is preferred, such as R, Matlab, or Python. For BSc in Data Science and Technology students only.

MATH6050H.COURSEID: MATH 6050H - Topics in Analysis and Related Issues (3 units)
MATH6050H.NAME: Topics in Analysis and Related Issues
MATH6050H.DESCRIPTION: This course will cover some selected topics in analysis and partial differential equations. Tentative topics include: nonlocal PDEs arising from mathematical physics and biology, theory of travelling wave solutions (existence and non-existence), asymptotics and stability.

MATH6050I.NAME: Real Analysis I
MATH6050I.DESCRIPTION: This course is an introduction to real analysis on abstract spaces. The following contents are covered: Integration on a measure space, the construction of measures from outer measures, Riesz representation theorem relating positive functionals to measures, Lebesque and Hausdorff measures, Lebesgue spaces and their duality, weak convergence of functions, signed measures and Radon-Nikodym theorem. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in Lebesgue integration on the real line and elements of functional analysis.

MATH6050J.NAME: Intermediate Complex Analysis
MATH6050J.DESCRIPTION: The objective is to familiarize students with concepts and techniques in Complex Analysis beyond an introductory course in Functions of a Complex Variable. This course covers a choice of topics in Complex Analysis in one complex variable such as complex potential theory, meromorphic functions, open Riemann surfaces, compact Riemann surfaces, normal families, geometric theory of holomorphic mappings and complex dynamics. Graded P or F.

MATH6150J.COURSEID: MATH 6150J - SL_2-triples in Representation Theory (3 units)
MATH6150J.NAME: SL_2-triples in Representation Theory
MATH6150J.DESCRIPTION: This course demonstrates how to apply algebraic techniques of SL_2-triples for studying geometric and analytic problems in representation theory of semisimple Lie groups.

MATH6388A.COURSEID: MATH 6388A - Advanced Numerical Analysis II (3 units)
MATH6388A.NAME: Advanced Numerical Analysis II
MATH6388A.DESCRIPTION:
This course covers basic numerical methods in the graduate level. The main themes 
are numerical solutions of PDEs and numerical methods for eigenvalue problems. For numerical solutions of PDEs, some basic theories of finite difference methods for hyperbolic equations are discussed. The topics include stability, order of accuracy, consistency, Lax-equivalence theorem, multistep methods, dissipation and 
dispersion, system of equations in higher dimensions, splitting schemes. For numerical methods for eigenvalue problems, the topics include the Gershgorin theorem, power iteration, inverse power iteration, Householder and Givens matrices, 
QR factorization, QR algorithm, singular value decomposition, principle component analysis, rank deficient problems, regularization techniques.

MATH6450G.COURSEID: MATH 6450G - High-Dimensional Probability: Theory and Applications (3 units)
MATH6450G.NAME: High-Dimensional Probability: Theory and Applications
MATH6450G.DESCRIPTION: This course covers some basic probabilistic methods and principles that arise frequently across a broad range of high-dimensional problems. Basic theoretical skills, such as concentration inequalities and suprema of random processes, for analyzing random vectors and random matrices will be introduced. Applications in machine learning, probabilistic combinatorics, and computer science will also be discussed.

MATH6450H.COURSEID: MATH 6450H - Mathematical Analysis of Machine Learning Algorithms (3 units)
MATH6450H.NAME: Mathematical Analysis of Machine Learning Algorithms
MATH6450H.DESCRIPTION: This is an advanced graduate course for students who are already familiar with basic machine learning algorithms such as support vector machines, decision trees, boosting, neural networks etc, and has learned the basic mathematical tools such as calculus, linear algebra, and probability. This is mainly a mathematical class, and the goal is to introduce the basic techniques in the theoretical analysis of machine learning algorithms, with motivations and applications.

MATH6913D.COURSEID: MATH 6913D - Reading Course: Stochastic Partial Differential Equations (3 units)
MATH6913D.NAME: Reading Course: Stochastic Partial Differential Equations
MATH6913D.DESCRIPTION: The reading course will give introduction to stochastic partial differential equations. Topics Include stochastic partial differential equations and solutions, space-time Gaussian white noise, applications, and singular equations. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913E.COURSEID: MATH 6913E - Reading Course: Toric Geometry (1 unit)
MATH6913E.NAME: Reading Course: Toric Geometry
MATH6913E.DESCRIPTION: We will study varieties with toric actions. The topic includes description of toric varieties via combinatorical data. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984N.COURSEID: MATH 4984N - Independent Study: Mathematical Aspect of Combinatorial Game (3 units)
MATH4984N.NAME: Independent Study: Mathematical Aspect of Combinatorial Game
MATH4984N.DESCRIPTION: We investigate how one can use basic combinatorial theory and computer programming technique (Python) to analyse the combinatorial game. Students may further develop the techniques to deepen the study of the game, or study other combinatorial games. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984O.COURSEID: MATH 4984O - Independent Study: A Course on Rough Paths (3 units)
MATH4984O.NAME: Independent Study: A Course on Rough Paths
MATH4984O.DESCRIPTION: This is an independent course on rough path analysis and its applications to SPDEs based on the book “A Course on Rough Paths; With an Introduction to Regularity Structures” by Peter K. Friz and Martin Hairer. The main focus will be the space of rough paths, Brownian motion as a rough path, integration against rough paths, stochastic integration and Ito’s formula, Doob-Meyer type decomposition for rough paths, operations on controlled rough paths, solutions to rough differential equations, stochastic differential equations, Gaussian rough paths, and so on. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984P.COURSEID: MATH 4984P - Independent Study: A Course on Approximate Message Passing (3 units)
MATH4984P.NAME: Independent Study: A Course on Approximate Message Passing
MATH4984P.DESCRIPTION:
This is an independent course on Approximate Message Passing algorithm and its applications, based on the following papers: 1: Bayati, M., Lelarge, M., & Montanari, A. (2015). Universality in polytope phase transitions and message passing algorithms. The Annals of Applied Probability, 25(2), 753-822. 2: Chen, W. K., & Lam, W. K. (2020). Universality of Approximate Message Passing Algorithms. arXiv preprint arXiv:2003.10431. 3: Fan, Z. (2020). Approximate Message Passing algorithms for rotationally invariant matrices. arXiv preprint arXiv:2008.11892. 
Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984Q.COURSEID: MATH 4984Q - Independent Study: Algorithmic Game Theory (3 units)
MATH4984Q.NAME: Independent Study: Algorithmic Game Theory
MATH4984Q.DESCRIPTION: This  is a reading course on algorithmic game theory. Students will read  selected chapters from the textbook Karlin, A. R., & Peres, Y. (2017). Game theory, alive (Vol. 101). American Mathematical Society along with other handouts. Students will be marked based on submitted solutions to assigned problems. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984R.COURSEID: MATH 4984R - Independent Study: Randomized Algorithms for Matrix Decompositions (3 units)
MATH4984R.NAME: Independent Study: Randomized Algorithms for Matrix Decompositions
MATH4984R.DESCRIPTION: This is an independent course on matrix decompositions using randomized algorithm and its applications. Students will read relative papers on randomized methods for matrix approximation including the following papers • N. Halko, P. G. Martinsson, and J. A. Tropp. 2011. Finding Structure with Randomness: Probabilistic Algorithms for Constructing Approximate Matrix Decompositions. SIAM Rev. 53, 2 (May 2011), 217–288. • P. G. Martinsson, and J. A. Tropp. 2020. Randomized numerical linear algebra: Foundations and algorithms. arXiv preprint 2002.01387. Students will also learn applications of the methods on the latest technologies, and try to explore new methods to solve real-world application problems with the guide of the instructor. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984S.COURSEID: MATH 4984S - Independent Study: Neural Network Technique (3 units)
MATH4984S.NAME: Independent Study: Neural Network Technique
MATH4984S.DESCRIPTION: In this project, an ensemble back-propagation neural network technique will be developed and used to estimate the spatial Aerosol optical depth (AOD) in the Greater Bay Area by combining the satellite remote sensing data, ground observation data, and numerical model data. The estimated AOD field in relatively high accuracy will then be assimilated into the 3D chemical transport model to further improve the photolysis rate simulation. The outcome of this project can assist us in better understanding the aerosol impacts on the radiation-related atmospheric chemistry reactions. Students should seek instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984T.COURSEID: MATH 4984T - Independent Study: Advanced Topics in Derivative Pricing (3 units)
MATH4984T.NAME: Independent Study: Advanced Topics in Derivative Pricing
MATH4984T.DESCRIPTION: The student will explore various models and methodologies for pricing equity derivatives in this independent study course. In addition, the student will also explore some advanced numerical techniques in obtaining approximation to the price of the derivative. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH5473.COURSEID: MATH 5473 - Topological and Geometric Data Reduction and Visualization (3 units)
MATH5473.NAME: Topological and Geometric Data Reduction and Visualization
MATH5473.DESCRIPTION: This course is a mathematical introduction to data analysis and visualization with a perspective of topology and geometry. Topics covered include: classical linear dimensionality reduction, the principal component analysis (PCA) and its dual multidimensional scaling (MDS), as well as extensions to manifold learning, topological data analysis, and sparse models in applied math/high dimensional statistics. Extensive application examples in biology, finance, and information technology are presented along with course projects.
MATH5473.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Explain the basics concept of dimensional reduction.
2.Use Compressed Sensing and High Dimensional Statistics techniques for data analysis.
3.Use Manifold learning approach for applications.
4.Apply the data analysis method in applications.

MATH6150K.COURSEID: MATH 6150K - Topics in Algebra II (3 units)
MATH6150K.NAME: Topics in Algebra II
MATH6150K.DESCRIPTION: In the tropical algebra, the sum of two numbers is their minimum, and the product is their sum. This makes polynomials into piecewise-linear functions and their zero sets into polyhedral complexes. Tropical geometry is a young subject that has undergone rapid development since the beginning of the 21st century. It provides a combinatorial shadow of algebraic geometry and algebraic groups, and reveals new and sometimes unexpected connections among different mathematical branches.

MATH6170D.COURSEID: MATH 6170D - An Introduction to Algebraic Number Theory (3 units)
MATH6170D.NAME: An Introduction to Algebraic Number Theory
MATH6170D.DESCRIPTION: This is an introduction to the algebraic number theory. The topics to be covered include: number fields, algebraic integers, factorization, Dedekind domains, local rings, Units and class groups, Cyclotomic fields, p-adic numbers, Dedekind Zeta functions, Artin Zeta functions. Other topics (depending on interest: Weil explicit formula, number field and function field analogy, etc..)

MATH6250D.NAME: Complex Manifolds
MATH6250D.DESCRIPTION: This course gives an introduction to basic notions on complex manifolds both on the algebraic side and on the analytic side, with an emphasis on compact complex manifolds. It will include sheaf theory, Cech cohomology, de Rham and Dolbeault cohomologies, Hermitian and Kähler manifolds, Hermitian holomorphic vector bundles, harmonic forms, vanishing theorems, Kodaira’s Embedding Theorem and Chern classes. We will also examine examples of classical compact complex manifolds, starting with projective spaces and their dual manifolds, i.e., compact quotients of the complex unit ball by torsion-free discrete lattices, illustrating in concrete terms how some of the aforementioned basic notions can be applied to the study of such classical manifolds. Graded P or F.

MATH6380T.COURSEID: MATH 6380T - Topics in Applied Dynamical Systems (3 units)
MATH6380T.NAME: Topics in Applied Dynamical Systems
MATH6380T.DESCRIPTION: Many problems in science and engineering are better understood as a dynamical system with internal mechanisms to evolve in time. This course illustrates how theories from dynamical systems can help analyze and interpret data with some recent developments. Particular emphasis will be given to the scenario where we have limited observations of a system consisting of a large number of variables, such as in the brain. We will first review classic stability and bifurcation theories and then discuss topics Including: theory and application of chaos, data-driven modeling and DMD, and fitting and Interpreting RNNs. The students will also have ample opportunity for hands-on practice of the discussed algorithms. The course is suited for both postgraduate and advanced undergraduate students. There is no formal prerequisite. However, the students are expected to be familiar with linear algebra, multivariable calculus, ordinary differential equations, basic probability, and statistics, and have experience in some programming language (e.g. python, MATLAB).

MATH6913F.COURSEID: MATH 6913F - Reading Course: Tensor Data Analysis (3 units)
MATH6913F.NAME: Reading Course: Tensor Data Analysis
MATH6913F.DESCRIPTION:
This course will introduce the statistical methods to analyze tensor data, related 
Optimization topics for fast computation, and covers relevant applications. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913G.COURSEID: MATH 6913G - Reading Course: Geometric Stochastic Analysis (3 units)
MATH6913G.NAME: Reading Course: Geometric Stochastic Analysis
MATH6913G.DESCRIPTION:
This is a reading course on Geometric Stochastic Analysis based on the book 
“Stochastic Analysis on Manifolds” by Elton. P. Hsu. The main focus will be 
Stochastic Differential Equations and Diffusions, Basic Stochastic Differential Geometry, Brownian Motion on Manifolds, Heat Semigroup. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913H.COURSEID: MATH 6913H - Reading Course: Selective Inference in Statistical Learning (3 units)
MATH6913H.NAME: Reading Course: Selective Inference in Statistical Learning
MATH6913H.DESCRIPTION: Read papers on selective inference etc and write reports. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913I.COURSEID: MATH 6913I - Reading Course: Sheets, Slodowy Slices and Nilpotent Orbits (2 units)
MATH6913I.NAME: Reading Course: Sheets, Slodowy Slices and Nilpotent Orbits
MATH6913I.DESCRIPTION: This reading course studies nilpotent orbits of reductive Lie algebras aiming at application to unitary representations of reductive Lie groups by the orbit method. It is based on the fundamental theory of nilpotent orbits and focused on algebraic and geometric aspects of the sheets of reductive Lie algebras, singularities of closures of nilpotent orbits and Slodowy slices. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913J.COURSEID: MATH 6913J - Reading Course: Data Science Methods in Quantitative Investment (2 units)
MATH6913J.NAME: Reading Course: Data Science Methods in Quantitative Investment
MATH6913J.DESCRIPTION:
Two related topics: 1) data-driven methods for option hedging and pricing, and 
2) factor models for asset pricing based on data mining. The data science methods
include regressions and machine learning. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6913K.COURSEID: MATH 6913K - Reading Course: Bio Rhythm Time Series Analysis and Applications (3 units)
MATH6913K.NAME: Reading Course: Bio Rhythm Time Series Analysis and Applications
MATH6913K.DESCRIPTION:
Bio-Rhythm is an important part of organisms. Recently it has gained traction as
an important tool for diagnosis. This project aims to analyze real data for cancer
detection and other potential diagnoses. Students are preferred to have the
background of basic data analysis.

MATH6916.COURSEID: MATH 6916 - Student Seminars on Computation Related Research (1 unit)
MATH6916.NAME: Student Seminars on Computation Related Research
MATH6916.DESCRIPTION: Seminar presentation on computation related research by students in the Scientific Computation Concentration (SCC) within the first four regular terms of study. Students should notify their major department 2-3 weeks in advance for the presentation. Graded P or F.
MATH6916.INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES:
On successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1.Demonstrate knowledge and understanding on computation related research.

MATH4984U.COURSEID: MATH 4984U - Independent Study: LDPC Codes (1 unit)
MATH4984U.NAME: Independent Study: LDPC Codes
MATH4984U.DESCRIPTION: The purpose of this course is to study the classical information theory and the theory of LDPC Codes.  Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984V.COURSEID: MATH 4984V - Independent Study: Using GeoGebra in Teaching Mathematics (1 unit)
MATH4984V.NAME: Independent Study: Using GeoGebra in Teaching Mathematics
MATH4984V.DESCRIPTION: In this course, the student will learn all the techniques of using GeoGebra, from the basic to the advanced ones.  Then the student needs to using the knowledge to produce a suite of interactive GeoGebra applets for teaching a specific topic in mathematics. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984W.COURSEID: MATH 4984W - Independent Study: Point Set Theory (3 units)
MATH4984W.NAME: Independent Study: Point Set Theory
MATH4984W.DESCRIPTION: The is a summer course on point set topology, similar to MATH 4225, that includes all basic concepts in point set topology. This is independent study, so the student is required to self-study the topics and do exercises. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984X.COURSEID: MATH 4984X - Independent Study: Weather Research Forecast Model and Flow Visualization (2 units)
MATH4984X.NAME: Independent Study: Weather Research Forecast Model and Flow Visualization
MATH4984X.DESCRIPTION: The student will learn how to run the Weather Research Forecast (WRF) model to look at marine emissions. He will examine the morphometric data using geographic information system (GIS) tools. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984Y.COURSEID: MATH 4984Y - Independent Study: Message Passing Algorithms for Compressed Sensing (3 units)
MATH4984Y.NAME: Independent Study: Message Passing Algorithms for Compressed Sensing
MATH4984Y.DESCRIPTION: This is an independent course on the applications of Message Pass Algorithms on Compressed Sensing.  It will be based on the following two papers: 1. Donoho, D., Maleki, A., & Montanari, A. (2011). How to Design Message Pass Algorithms for Compressed Sensing. 2. Donoho, D.L., Maleki, A., & Montanari, A. (2009). Message-passing algorithms for compressed sensing. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4984Z.COURSEID: MATH 4984Z - Independent Study: Information Theory and Error-correcting Codes (1 unit)
MATH4984Z.NAME: Independent Study: Information Theory and Error-correcting Codes
MATH4984Z.DESCRIPTION: The purpose of this course is to study information theory in general, both in classical and quantum setting, and to study the latest development on the theory of error-correcting codes. This is a self-study course. There will be meetings from time to time and each student is expected to give at least one lecture. Homework will be assigned and collected. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4985A.COURSEID: MATH 4985A - Independent Study: Commutative Algebra (2 units)
MATH4985A.NAME: Independent Study: Commutative Algebra
MATH4985A.DESCRIPTION: The course is to study basic materials in commutative algebra. The book of the course is "Introduction to Commutative Algebra" written by Atiyah and MacDonald. Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH4985B.COURSEID: MATH 4985B - Independent Study: Coxeter Groups and Hecke Algebras (1 unit)
MATH4985B.NAME: Independent Study: Coxeter Groups and Hecke Algebras
MATH4985B.DESCRIPTION: The is a reading course to cover the modern theory of Coxeter groups and Iwahori-Hecke algebras.  Students should seek the course instructor's approval to take this course.

MATH6150L.COURSEID: MATH 6150L - Introduction to Modular Forms and Automorphic Forms (3 units)
MATH6150L.NAME: Introduction to Modular Forms and Automorphic Forms
MATH6150L.DESCRIPTION: This is an introductory course into the subject of modular forms and their generalization of automorphic forms. Some knowledge in complex analysis and algebraic geometry will be helpful. A modular form is a complex analytic function defined on the complex upper half plane which has a certain symmetry with respect to the action of the modular group SL(2,Z) (or a congruence subgroup) on the upper half plane and which satisfies some growth condition.
